title: Finance Commission and Fiscal Federalism in India

information.title: Finance Commission
information.description: The Finance Commission is a constitutional body established under Article 280 of the Indian Constitution. It is appointed every five years to recommend the distribution of net proceeds of taxes between the Centre and the States.

information.title: Composition
information.description: The Finance Commission consists of a Chairman and four other members appointed by the President. They hold office for the duration specified by the President in the order of appointment.

information.title: Functions
information.description: The primary functions of the Finance Commission include recommending the distribution of taxes between the Centre and States, principles governing grants-in-aid to States, and measures to augment the Consolidated Fund of a State to supplement the resources of Panchayats and Municipalities.

information.title: Fiscal Federalism
information.description: Fiscal federalism refers to the financial relations between the Centre and States in India. It involves the division of taxing powers and expenditure responsibilities between different levels of government.

information.title: Revenue Sharing
information.description: The Finance Commission recommends the share of states in the central taxes. This is called the divisible pool. The 15th Finance Commission recommended 41% of the divisible pool to be transferred to States for the period 2021-26.

information.title: Grants-in-Aid
information.description: Besides tax devolution, the Finance Commission also recommends grants-in-aid to states that need assistance. These can be general purpose grants or specific purpose grants.
